required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Gastroenteritis From Rotavirus Infection in Brazilian Children Less Than 5 Years of Age (Study V260-031).
clinical_study.official_title: Rotavirus Gastroenteritis in Children Up to 5 Years of Age. Surveillance Performed in Hospitals From Four Brazilian Regions.

brief_summary.textblock: This is a 1-year study evaluating hospitalizations and the medical care for the treatment of diarrhea from rotavirus infection in children < 5 years of age, conducted in four hospitals located in four Brazilian regions. A stool sample from each eligible child passing 3 or more loose stools or watery stools within a period of 24 hours and requiring hospitalization or rehydration therapy (oral or IV rehydration) will be tested for the presence of rotavirus, using standard laboratory procedures (ie, Enzyme Linked Ligand Sorbent Assay, or ELlSA) by all participating hospitals.

primary_outcome.measure: The Number of Hospitalizations for Diarrhea in Children up to 5 Years of Age
primary_outcome.description: The total number of hospitalizations for diarrhea in children up to 5 years of age in the 4 Brazilian hospital research centers was reported. Diarrhea was defined as the passage of 3 or more soft/liquid feces in a 24-hour period.

primary_outcome.measure: The Percentage of Hospitalizations for Diarrhea in Children up to 5 Years of Age
primary_outcome.description: The percentage of total hospitalizations for children up to 5 years of age in the 4 Brazilian hospital research centers that were for diarrhea. Diarrhea was defined as the passage of 3 or more soft/liquid feces in a 24-hour period.

primary_outcome.measure: The Geographic Distribution of Hospitalizations for Diarrhea That Are Caused by Rotavirus
primary_outcome.description: Children up to 5 years of age hospitalized for diarrhea were tested for fecal rotavirus as determined by enzyme immunoassay. Diarrhea was defined as the passage of 3 or more soft/liquid feces in a 24-hour period. For each geographic location, the number of hospitalizations for diarrhea that was caused by rotavirus was reported.

primary_outcome.measure: The Percentage of Hospitalizations for Diarrhea That Are Caused by Rotavirus
primary_outcome.description: Children up to 5 years of age hospitalized for diarrhea were tested for fecal rotavirus as determined by enzyme immunoassay. Diarrhea was defined as the passage of 3 or more soft/liquid feces in a 24-hour period. The number of hospitalizations for diarrhea from rotavirus infection was divided by the total number of hospitalizations for diarrhea in the 4 hospital research centers.

primary_outcome.measure: The Number of Hospitalizations for Diarrhea That Are Caused by Rotavirus by Age Group
primary_outcome.description: Children up to 5 years of age hospitalized for diarrhea were tested for fecal rotavirus as determined by enzyme immunoassay. Diarrhea was defined as the passage of 3 or more soft/liquid feces in a 24-hour period. The number of hospitalizations for diarrhea from rotavirus infection was reported for each age group.

primary_outcome.measure: The Numbers of Participants Hospitalized for Diarrhea and Rotavirus-caused Diarrhea Per Month
primary_outcome.description: Children up to 5 years of age hospitalized for diarrhea were tested for fecal rotavirus as determined by enzyme immunoassay. Diarrhea was defined as the passage of 3 or more soft/liquid feces in a 24-hour period.

primary_outcome.measure: The Duration of Hospitalization for Participants Enrolled in the Study
primary_outcome.description: The mean duration (days) of hospital stay for children up to 5 years of age hospitalized for diarrhea in the 4 Brazilian hospital research centers. Diarrhea was defined as the passage of 3 or more soft/liquid feces in a 24-hour period.

primary_outcome.measure: The Number of Deaths in Hospitalized Participants Enrolled in the Study
primary_outcome.description: The number of deaths among children up to 5 years of age hospitalized for diarrhea in the 4 Brazilian hospital research centers. Diarrhea was defined as the passage of 3 or more soft/liquid feces in a 24-hour period.

arm_group.description: Brazilian children under 5 years of age who have diarrhea attributed to rotavirus located in 4 hospitals from 4 different Brazilian regions

intervention.description: This is an observational study evaluating hospitalizations and the medical care for the treatment of diarrhea from rotavirus infection in children < 5 years of age; however, any rotavirus vaccines used in the children presenting with rotavirus-attributed diarrhea were evaluated, as well the prevalent rotavirus serotypes in this sample for future vaccine development.

study_pop.textblock: Children less than 5 years of age from four Brazilian cities with diarrhea attributed to rotavirus infection.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- a child < 5 years of age being treated for acute gastroenteritis within 72 hours prior to evaluation in the study hospitals.
- outpatient children < 5 years of age submitted for treatment of acute gastroenteritis within 72 hours prior to evaluation in the study clinics.
Exclusion Criteria:
- none specified

overall_official.last_name: Divina das Dores P Cardoso, Doctor
overall_official.affiliation: Instituto de Patologia Tropical e Saúde Pública IPTSP-UFG
Hospital Santo Antonio - Obras Sociais Irma Dulce
Hospital Universitário da Universidade de Sao Paulo
Hospital de Clínicas da Universidade Federal do Rio de Grande do Sul

group.title: Children Hospitalized For Diarrhea
group.description: Children up to 5 years of age hospitalized for diarrhea in the 4 Brazilian hospital research centers

group.title: Children Who Provided a Fecal Sample
group.description: Children up to 5 years of age hospitalized for diarrhea and providing a fecal sample in the 4 Brazilian hospital research centers. Diarrhea was defined as the passage of 3 or more soft/liquid feces in a 24-hour period.

outcome.title: The Number of Hospitalizations for Diarrhea in Children up to 5 Years of Age
outcome.description: The total number of hospitalizations for diarrhea in children up to 5 years of age in the 4 Brazilian hospital research centers was reported. Diarrhea was defined as the passage of 3 or more soft/liquid feces in a 24-hour period.
outcome.population: The population analyzed was all enrolled participants whether or not a fecal sample was obtained

measure.population: The population analyzed was all enrolled participants whether or not a fecal sample was obtained

outcome.title: The Percentage of Hospitalizations for Diarrhea in Children up to 5 Years of Age
outcome.description: The percentage of total hospitalizations for children up to 5 years of age in the 4 Brazilian hospital research centers that were for diarrhea. Diarrhea was defined as the passage of 3 or more soft/liquid feces in a 24-hour period.
outcome.population: The population to be analyzed was all hospitalizations for any reason for children up to 5 years of age in the 4 hospital research centers The number of total hospitalizations for children up to 5 years of age was not known; thus this outcome measure was not evaluated

group.title: Children Hospitalized for Diarrhea
group.description: Children hospitalized for diarrhea in the 4 Brazilian hospital research centers

measure.title: The Percentage of Hospitalizations for Diarrhea in Children up to 5 Years of Age
measure.description: The percentage of total hospitalizations for children up to 5 years of age in the 4 Brazilian hospital research centers that were for diarrhea. Diarrhea was defined as the passage of 3 or more soft/liquid feces in a 24-hour period.

outcome.title: The Geographic Distribution of Hospitalizations for Diarrhea That Are Caused by Rotavirus
outcome.description: Children up to 5 years of age hospitalized for diarrhea were tested for fecal rotavirus as determined by enzyme immunoassay. Diarrhea was defined as the passage of 3 or more soft/liquid feces in a 24-hour period. For each geographic location, the number of hospitalizations for diarrhea that was caused by rotavirus was reported.
outcome.population: The population analyzed was children up to 5 years of age hospitalized for diarrhea. A total of 190 of the 230 participants had fecal samples analyzed; 27 of these had stool samples positive for rotavirus.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The initial publication of this study will be multicenter, comprising data from all sites involved. After the multicenter publication, or 24 months after the end of the study, each site involved may publish its own results in an independent fashion. The sponsor will also have the opportunity to review all the proposed abstracts, manuscripts or lectures related to this study 60 days before submission for publication/presentation.

point_of_contact.name_or_title: Senior Vice President, Global Clinical Development
